title: CI/CD pipeline that enables Moore’s law and and propels the world to the future

ASML scanners have multiple computers inside with multiple operating systems, running software stack of >50 mil lines of code on multiple languages from C till Python and Julia. Those scanners are able to position silicon wafers with nanometer accuracy and several G of acceleration.

title: Distributed applications - Better off with frameworks, Kubernetes, service meshes or all of them at once?
summary: Distributed software architecture based on microservices can provide several advantages, but also new challenges that need to be addressed in a specific way. One approach to address these challenges is to use service meshes, but another option is to Leverage the power of eBPF technology. The talk will provide a overview of these approaches and how they can be used together to create a successful distributed software architecture.
:LABEL: Talk

title: Distributed Tracing as Architecture
summary: In this talk, I want to give a very pragmatic approach on creating the architecture of a (new) system. And it's not only drawing boxes and lines or pitching some tool. It starts with a short but intense design phase and then validating and evolving the architecture from a running application using distributed tracing. :LABEL: Talk

title: Docker Compose: From Localhost to Cloud

We will show you some advanced use cases that you might use as a developer on your local machine. But did you know that Ops can also take advantage of Docker Compose by deploying an entire application to the Cloud? Yes, in a single command an entire application can be deployed to your Cloud provider without the need of Kubernetes.
:LABEL: Talk

summary: Generational garbage collection (GCC) can improve the timeliness of your services by allowing concurrent garbage collection to complete in less time than is required for traditional Shenandoah full garbage collection cycles. This means less memory is required for new allocations and floating garbage and fewer CPU resources are required by the concurrent GC worker threads.

summary: Frontend development is getting more and more complex when using JavaScript frameworks like Angular or React. On top of that, the landscape is also rapidly changing. Developers claim that this is needed to build the highly interactive web experiences we all come to know and like. However, that is not true. It has an intuitive UI, and can be saved in common formats. In this session, I'll cover why realistic data is useful, and how to create a realistic dataset with mockaroo.

title: OpenTelemetry – An Observability Framework for Cloud-Native Software
summary: In cloud-native technology stacks, distributed and polyglot architectures are the norm. Distributed architectures introduce a variety of operational challenges including how to solve availability and performance issues quickly. These challenges have led to the rise of observability. Telemetry data is needed to power observability products. Traditionally, telemetry data has been provided by either open-source projects or commercial vendors.
:LABEL: Talk

title: Optimizing Speed and Scale of Real-Time Analytics Using Apache Pulsar and Apache Pinot
summary: Apache Pulsar is a new generation of platform that offers enterprise-grade event streaming and processing capabilities built for today's Cloud Native environment. But what do you do if you want to perform user-facing, ad-hoc, real-time analytics too? That's where Apache Pinot comes in. Apache Pinot is a realtime distributed OLAP datastore, which is used to deliver scalable real time analytics with low latency.
:LABEL: Talk

title: The Art of Java Language Pattern Matching
summary: Project Amber is exploring the inclusion of smaller, productivity-oriented Java language features, including pattern matching. In JDK 14, JEP 305 introduced pattern matching for instanceof, and in JDK 16, this was made a full feature through JEP 394. In JDK 17, JEP 406 added pattern matching for switch. In this session, we'll look at the details of these two new language features and a more general look at pattern matching.
:LABEL: Talk

title: The lost art of software design
summary: Big design up front is dumb. Doing no design up front is even dumber. This quote epitomises what I've seen during our journey from big design up front in the 20th century, to emergent design and evolutionary architecture in the 21st. In their desire to become agile, many teams seem to have abandoned architectural thinking, up front design, documentation, diagramming, and modeling. In many cases this is a
:LABEL: Talk

title: The next generation of Angular Applications
summary: Module support is now optional in Angular 14, and standalone components are now the component of choice for Angular applications. This release also introduces composition APIs, dynamic form handling, and a new way to title single page applications. This talk will cover these new features and how they might change the way we architect our applications.
:LABEL: Talk

title: Things I Wish I Knew When I Started Testing Spring Boot Applications
summary: Testing is an important part of software development, and Spring Boot makes it easy to get started. In this talk, I'll give you tips on how to get started testing your Spring Boot applications.
:LABEL: Talk

title: Threading lightly with Kotlin
summary:
This session intends to demonstrate the differences between concurrency models based on threads and concurrency models based on coroutines. We will discuss what coroutines are and what they are not, and answer questions such as:

- How different are coroutines and Threads?
- Are there any new pitfalls that developers should be aware of?
- Do the traditional synchronization methods available in the JRE still apply?
:LABEL: Talk

title: Why don't you create your next application without a database?
summary: MicroStream is a new, revolutionary way of storing data within the JVM. It eliminates the impedance mismatch between the Java object-oriented world and the external data storage, and allows you to query the data instances within the JVM memory extremely quickly and with low latency.
:LABEL: Talk

title: Why you should be using OpenTelemetry!
:LABEL: Talk

title: Will Git Be Around Forever? A List of Possible Successors
summary: In this talk I'll discuss a few post-Git products, including Fossil, Plastic and Pijul, and their support for the features we so dearly desire. I'll also try to predict which one will be 'the top dog' in 2032.
:LABEL: Talk

title: Women's journey in tech
summary: The technology industry benefits from an environment that is diverse in terms of ideas, backgrounds, and experiences. However, the pool of female candidates is not large enough to compensate for this gap, and the challenges that exist discourage women from joining and staying in the industry. The goal of this discussion is to share the lived experiences of women in the technology industry in order to motivate others to contribute and help make the tech environment more diverse.
:LABEL: Talk

title: Word Embeddings from Deep Space Nine using Machine Learning.

title: You shall not password
summary: In these modern times of real privacy protection and increased server-side security, a key risk can still be defined as “relying on a single word or phrase to protect all of one’s data”. Consider a password a secret you happily seem to share with the world wide web. Ponder the thought: if you start sharing your secret, can it still be considered a secret?
:LABEL: Talk

title: Zero trust privacy architecture for IoT SaaS

title: Zero Trust Security for your APIs
